column4: okay.... so you guys are probably going to be sick of a question like this... but I am completely new.  I went to the home page for Ubuntu, downloaded the .iso, burned it to disk, stuck it in the machine I am going to install it on... and got  "No init found. Try passing init=bootarg."  I have no clue what to do from there
burned with sonic in Windows XP...loaded it as an iso disk image
an MD5 sum is an algorithm to make sure the file you downloaded is downloaded correctly, with no parts corrupted
there are a couple programs for Windows XP that can check to make sure that the md5 is correct on the iso.
the Ubuntu website has the md5 checksum of the iso
if you don;t have a usb stick don't listen to anyone who wants you to use one
do you still have the file you downloaded on the computer?

when I was trying to fgure out what it meant... i kept getting so much info that is way beyond me.  I dont know console... people were saying it had something to do with the install... i am trying to install this on a brand new hard drive
you'll get that, let me try looking for one specific to this condition
most people are solving this error on already installed systems by using a file-system check, "fsck"
os CDs are very sensitive and generally won't work if a few bytes didnt copy well
the one on the download page would probably work great
should I burn it slower than max?  just in case...
